Answer: We have, or can imagine, the technology but have not found answers for many of the physiological difficulties the human body faces living with substantially more or less than 1 G gravity (anything inside 1G +/- 30% seems sustainable but outside that is known to cause serious problems). We have yet to find a consistent and ample supply of water, oxygen, food and fuel and can not possibly take enough with us. We do not yet have the technology to terraform even a small area of the Moon or Mars and have not found actual quantities necessary for prolonged habitation,

Answer: I have to disagree with the other answers here, though it might be a matter of definitions as much as anything else. We won’t be able to colonize “space” for a very, very long time. I’m using the term “colony” to refer to a self-sustaining settlement that can continue to thrive without large-scale support from nations that established it. We’ve got a lot of problems to solve before we can do that.What we can do is set up permanently-staffed outposts. We could probably set those up on the Moon or Mars within 20 years, but only if we were willing to expend a lot of resources to do it.
